awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Quantitative Studies of Career Trajectories for African American Women in  Engineering and Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
The lack of progress in broadening the participation of African American women in the academy, industry and tech entrepreneurship remains at the margins despite years of interventions and initiatives frequently intended for women and minorities.  Innovative approaches are warranted to address seemingly intractable issues and ensure progress. This project combines data collection, quantitative analysis, social and behavioral sciences and simulations to elucidate factors that underlie the career trajectories of African American women.  These findings can, then, provide insights for the development of meaningful strategies and interventions to increase the participation and career success of African American women in engineering and computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.inst_name: Franklin W. Olin College of Engineering
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: FRANKLIN W. OLIN COLLEGE OF ENGINEERING, INC.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Franklin W. Olin College of Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Development of a diverse workforce in engineering and computing has significant implications for the nation’s security and well-being, economic growth, broadened scope of inquiry, elimination of inequities and overall ability to innovate and compete. Yet, for a number of complex and interrelated reasons, African American/Black women remain severely underrepresented and untapped. The lack of progress in broadening the participation of African American women in the academy, industry and technical entrepreneurship despite years of research and interventions for women and minorities, suggests that African American women, positioned at the intersection of race and gender, may be slipping through the cracks. New systematic approaches are called for to address seemingly intractable issues and ensure progress. To that end, the project, EAGER: Quantitative Studies of Career Trajectories for African American Women in Engineering and Computing was designed to increase the career trajectories and success of African American women faculty through the development of predictive models and the application of effective strategies for career advancement resulting from those models.

To facilitate our work, we developed Project GRACES (Gender and Race in Academic Career Experiences in STEM), https://gracesproject.com/. Through GRACES, we held a series of interactive workshops with a core group of Women of Color faculty to assist in identifying key factors to form a conceptual model to inform our agent-based simulation model. After developing a proof-of-concept simulation of the tenure track journey considering factors such the presence of absence of biases on equal representation at milestones, learnings from the workshops were used to further develop and refine the simulation. The simulation followed the detailed experiences of individuals over time and captured the causal links that lead from daily experiences to overall career advancement. The simulation also enabled us to test a range of what-if scenarios on various mitigation strategies. Results confirmed that the probability of career success for women is influenced by race and gender, and that African American women face disproportionate barriers. 

The project brought a novel, quantitative approach to measuring the impact of diversity on the careers of African American women and other underrepresented groups in academia. It also demonstrated the scientific value of agent-based simulations as a tool to analyze complex problems of this type, and to identify mitigation and improvement strategies. 

 


Last Modified: 02/14/2024
Modified by: Gilda A Barabino
